content.body: oh, damn
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/urls.html#reflecting-content-attributes-in-idl-attributes
this reflect section is a mess :/
It's a lot saner than what browsers actually do.
Hixie: Where did you get the "4 of 18 specs we reference are PR or REC" number?
I assume you were referring to >
> ~fantasai
Argh, not that.
http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/refs.html
i was reading the internal one, but yes
the only w3c specs are HTML4, PNG, UAAG and XML
and there are 18 specs
in the normative section
personally these days i just always reference the editor's drafts
solves the versioning issue altogether
Yeah, definitely.

5 points to anyone who can work out why the HTML spec says "except when stated otherwise in the algorithms given in the sections below" at http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete.html#dropEffect-initialization
Because an implementor made it "none" at all times after reading the version of that line without the qualification?
as far as i can tell, there are no cases where it is stated otherwise
i'm very confused
for those events it should always be "none", no?
Oh, you're wondering why *you* wrote it that way.
yeah
sorry, it wasn't a quiz :-)
i'm actually trying to work it out
Don't give out points, then
heh
the table has "none" for all three of those events, without qualification
TabAtkins_: if the csswg decides to test fewer things (as seems likely), submit the tests that are removed to the htmlwg's test suite :-)
kk!
we really should just have one "web" test suite
but that's another story
Agreed.  The web is constructed out of solid interactions, so trying to treat those interactions as out-of-scope is both fruitless and dangerous.
yeah
ok. for the record, the html spec right now has most of its drag and drop engine on the garage floor, but i'll have it back together either later today or tomorrow.
for now though... afk.
Heh, howcome just got called an "incompetent developer".
(Though he's not a developer at all, far as I know.)
TabAtkins_: Where?
www-style, writing-mode thread.
TabAtkins_, it's kind of ridiculously disingenuous to say that because ISO standards or RFCs are not technically called "Recommendations", they're comparable to HTML5.
Every normative reference in CSS2.1 is basically fixed and unchanging, HTML5 is not.
I agree.  HTML5 is more stable and mature than most of either.
HTML5 is more stable than an RFC?
"stable and mature".
Many RFCs aren't both.
Stable and mature implies, in particular, stable.
HTML5 is not stable by anyone's standards.
The part we were testing certainly is.
And if it's not, it's because the browser landscape changed, and tests should be updated accordingly.
You're acting like you're trying to challenge the entire W3C REC process.
In rejecting the necessity of fixed snapshots.
No, I'm trying to fight the ridiculous assertion that it's okay to test for behavior that's specified in HTML4 incorrectly, but in HTML5 correctly, because HTML5 isn't a REC.
I'm all for that, but the process revolves around fixed snapshots, and HTML5 is not a fixed snapshot.  You could suggest we reference the WD of a particular date . . .
That's still not a Rec, which is the criterion being used to suggest that we can't reference HTML5.
Yes, I know.
The problem is in saying that tests have to correspond to CSS 2.1, not in the fact that CSS 2.1 doesn't normatively reference HTML5.
There should be a "CSS test suite" that includes tests for all CSS-related stuff.  Or just one big "web test suite".
You should just agree that the tests don't have to go with CSS2.1's tests.  What difference does it make anyway where they're put?
That's not the problem either, unless you're suggesting that doing so would let us get around the "must reference RECs" because it's not tied to something trying to achieve REC.
AryehGregor: None at all, but it does matter that it's tested *somewhere*.  Just saying that it's out of scope and dropping the test doesn't help.
Well, obviously.  So test it somewhere else.
IMO it's not that interesting from a CSS POV, as CSS should just reflect whatever is in the DOM, and that's just as well covered by less contraversial tests.
gsnedders: It's important to know that browsers correctly reflect the value of minimized boolean attributes to the CSS engine.
AryehGregor: I've got no problem with that.  I just don't want it dropped, which, without any current work on another test suite, is what I fear will end up happening.
TabAtkins_: If we want to test that we need way more tests, for where it's empty, and where it's not equal to the attribute name
Yes...?

AryehGregor: fwiw, i _am_ trying to challenge the entire W3C REC process
AryehGregor: i think it's an archaic and obsolete practice that is stunting the development of the web

that is, the big picture's

though I'd be surprised if people running NoScript were both common and likely to submit junk

and some people have scripting disabled...
why doesn't whatever script receives the submission have server-side filtering?
it does
it's us

"black hole setup"
it sucks like a black hole?

but basically there's no discussion there whatsoever

that does not at all foster mutual understanding
to get mutual understanding with pfwg you need to explain your comment in a telecon
i've had to do that twice for my DTD comment
I have found that being on a telecon is about as productive as watching an episode of Twin Peaks

except the latter is way more fun

we published

hmm http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-xml-proc-profiles-20101021/
getting 503 for /TR/WebIDL/
working now
very slow though
I'm working slowly as well!
annevk, anyone - using an XHR request with followRedirects = true; and where /A 3xx's to /B - how do you get the URI "/B" back out from XHR?
it's not set or used in the responseXML, it's not in any of the properties of xhr, and not in any of the returned headers and a getResponseHeader("Location") =s null
hmm, I should remove followRedirects
but euh, I'd guess xhr.responseXML.URL or some such has it
well followRedirects is very useful.. but would be useful to have a .url or .location property on there that shows the URL of the final get request
useful and incomplete, yes
and the complete sultion is a whole bit more complicated
annvk, no it doesn't.. xhr.responseXML.URL and documentURI and all other properties are set to "/A" not "/B"
solution, even
that seems like a bug
could be, there's def no way to get "/B" back out though, tried everything
annevk, see: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2010Oct/0126.html for full details and corresponding TAG issue where it came up
I'm on that list
as I said, seems like a bug, is it the same in every browser?
will just check (re every browser)
it's pretty obvious that relative URLs in the resulting document need to be resolved against the URL of the resulting document
I guess we could test that in the XMLHttpRequest test suite...

annevk, tested and send response on list, cc'd you and public-webapps, turns out Firefox only exposes "/B" and Opera+Chrome only expose "/A" - and all 3 only expose as part of responseXML (so can't be used for non-dom-based responses)
sure, at some point we might need something special
and please don't cc me if you already cc a list I'm subscribed to
now I get 3 emails from Julian...
and three from you, come to think of it
sigh
lol apologies annevk - I get that often myself

when the content attribute is the empty string (or not set), the IDL attribute reflecting an URL should return the current URL ?
volkmar, depends I think
volkmar, I think for <a> there's no link in that case
volkmar, however for <form> there is
annevk: but the reflection algorithm should be the same in both case according to the specs
hmm
does that reflect implementations?
(no pun intended)
annevk: Gecko is returning the empty string if the content attribute isn't set
i can check with other UA's but I don't know what should be done per specs
annevk: webkit and gecko returns the empty string and opera returns the domain name (at least "localhost" locally... that's weird)
that does sound weird

my reasoning was based on test *not* creating a link and
creating a form
looks in HTML5
volkmar, HTML5 says "If the content attribute is absent, the IDL attribute must return the default value, if the content attribute has one, or else the empty string."
annevk: damn, i missed that... it's after the setting part
annevk: thanks :)
finds that <base>.href is special per HTML5
interesting, I think because of FireSheep, we will see a new set of tools (bad and good) on awareness - http://jonty.co.uk/idiocy

less prone to "easy hacking"

annevk: Our implementation is currently built on SQLite as well, actually.  But we'll be swapping that out in the future - it was just done because, hey, storage model we don't have to think about too much.
"Note that, in HTML5, U+000D is a valid literal character, but the entity &#x0D is not valid and is therefore not decoded." - it's not?
Well it's not valid
It is decoded

(since it is replaced by LF)

Hixie: @-rules that establish name-value mappings (like @keyframes) are document-global, not stylesheet-import-graph-local.  So you'll have to add some stuff to @scoped.
that's dumb
it means that style sheets can interfere with each other even without knowing each other
Well, if it's just sheet-local, then you can't, say, use an animation in @style.
But yes, it does mean that.
what's the use case for that?
The use-case for setting an animation in @style?
for setting an animation in style="" when you know you have to also declare it elsewhere
why not just do it all in the same place
use a class or some such
style=""'s use case is rapid prototyping and exceptions, i.e. for doing things when you're not editing a style sheet
Heh, but the class name could clash with other things as well.  ^_^
if you have to edit a style sheet anyway, its use case is gone
the class names are owned by the document
not the sheets
so that's fine
Another use, though, is declaring a lot of animations in one sheet, then using it elsewhere.
@import the sheet
@import should definitely get the declarations

The class name that would be required to add the animation could clash with the class name needed for another feature in another sheet, same as, say, keyframe names in one sheet could clash with keyframe names in another sheet.
Same failure point.
no, not at all
the class names are an interface presented by the document to the sheets
a contract if you will
I fail to see how you get any additional protection from clobbering.
while the key frames are for use within a sheet
Your definitions are well and good, but in terms of clobbering potential they're still identical.
two sheets can both have a contract with a document and thus use its styles, while both using animations and not knowing about each other
anyway, y'all do what you want, i just think it's silly :-) mail me or file a bug if the html spec needs to change
Will do.
(as i see it it's basically duplicating the mistake we've made many times in the web platform, with e.g. variables in JS)
(global scope is almost always a design failure, imho)
I don't disagree in general.
(a symptom of which is that the scoped style sheet feature has to define how it works -- it really should Just Work in such situations, imho)
Done:
Done: http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=11149
